growing in your yard, you can kill it with herbicide or just straight up 
rip it out of the ground but it will at the sign of any foreign harm 
release a spores that will take in said foreign anomoly and instead evolve 
with it. So if it's ripped out of the ground it will evolve to be able to 
carry itself better to plant somewhere else or evolve to grow on inorganic 
material. With the herbicide it will evolve with the herbicide inside it so 
that it will no longer be effective. That's just how fungi tend to work. So 
if they were taken out of their natural environment then it'd have to adapt 
to the newest host: dogs, cats, cattle, and yes humans.

comments.text:
+paul nathan also take into account that Human teeth isn't designed like a 
common predator. It isn't build to penetrate raw live meat and break bones 
as portrayed by every single Zombie or zombie like infections seen in 
movies and video games. The common conception is the fact that u have to be 
bitten for the virus to spread, rather than a sneeze or a touch makes 
zombification even more difficult for it to spread when u look at it at a 
logical basis. By the time it hits a million ,the government would have 
more than enough time to wipe them out but they probably wouldn't need to 
as people themselves will probably take them out with ease.

So logically speaking. I would rather see a Zombie like pandemic than a new 
type of super virus that can't be cured easily. The black death and the 
Spanish flu like pandemic are much more harder to fight when they are new. 
Those viruses have many ways to get into your body than a virus from an 
infected Zombie. Another words, zombie's can be controlled with force and 
with modern technologically advance weapons, that wont be hard. A pandemic 
of a super virus may spread with ease and kill millions to billions, 
silently and ferociously. Logic always win when u think. Given the fact 
that Zombie pandemic as we know it is almost impossible, when u still 
compare it to realm of possibility then u can say its just noway near as 
the most destructible virus.

comments.text:
+THE1gameaddict Ah sorry for not clarifying! Basically HIV is really weak. 
Familiar with the term "Glass Cannon" ? What it means is that it's 
powerful, but easily broken. For HIV, it can only survive inside our bodies 
where it is warm, isn't too acidic, has a lot of host cells to replicate 
in. When exposed to even small environment changes - like our saliva where 
it is too acidic - it dies. Same with stomach acid and our entire gut. 
Wayyy to hostile for it to survive, and also why it doesn't spread by 
sneezing or in the air, it's too weak. Blood and semen however, are an 
ideal acidity which stays the same no matter what, have host cells, and is 
usually warm and quickly transferred (which is why it's so important to 
wear a condom). Basically, the butcher could only have gotten the precursor 
HIV (not the modern version we know, but like a prototype) by blood 
transfer from an ape that he was chopping up for dinner; and yes, they did 
eat chimps. It's a food source, plain and simple. They could have also been 
hunters who skinned it for the pelt.

Either way, The blood simple trickled into an open wound, infused with his 
blood, and the HIV spread into it's first human host.

still not survive. Surviving isn't about strength, it's about tactics and 
wisdom. You may be strong having a machete against someone with a knife but 
if that someone with a knife is smart and has good tactics, you have a low 
chance of killing that someone. In the walking dead lee and clementine 
covered themselves in zombie guts to get past the zombies, that kind of 
thing would help you survive, making a noise and attracting attention with 
a gun will not. If I could choose between a rifle and a pistol I'd choose a 
pistol because it's not as loud. If I had the choice of a machine gun and 
knife I would choose a knife. Strength doesn't always help you, wisdom 
does. A wise one would know when and where to use a gun and when and where 
to use stealth. What I'm saying is that you shouldn't always rely on your 
strength.
comments.author: Natasha Elrick

comments.text:
Nope. Knowing your way around a gun and also having a parent in the 
military won't ensure your survival. In a zombie apocalypse, the amount of 
factors you haven't taken into account are MASSIVE. Firstly: The zombies 
themselves. They have three things going for them: Huge numbers, being 
difficult to kill and also they're absolutely terrifying. You might be 
confronted with 50 zombies. So, first off, you won't be able to shoot them 
all before they reach you. Second, you'll be scared shitless, most likely. 
Third, assuming the typical zombie of today's pop culture, the only way to 
completely kill a zombie would be destroying the brain, so lots of accurate 
headshots would be required, and since you're scared of the numbers, you 
might not be able to shoot straight. Also, ammunition isn't infinite.

Moving on from the zombies, you've got other humans. In a zombie 
apocalypse, the biggest danger is not the zombies, but other humans trying 
to survive. They are MORE than happy with killing you to get access to 
supplies, and they too will probably have weapon, which they will know how 
to use. Plus, some people have nerves of STEEL, man. They won't bat an eye 
as they shoot your head off so they can get that truck full of tinned food 
you were grabbing.

In addition, in a zombie apocalypse, healthcare is not a thing. You will be 
unlikely to be able to properly treat serious injuries you get, and 
infections would be high in number. On top of that, if you were to say, cut 
your knee before you got into a fight with a horde of Zombies, the killing 
could be your downfall. OK, so, you fight a dozen zombies with your cut 
knee. You blow one away. Then you shoot another one's legs out from under 
it, causing it to come at you in a slow crawl. Then, you blow away another. 
The other 9 then get closer to you. You back away, but slowly, because 
you're hampered by your badly cut knee. You shoot another zombie, and the 
bullet hits its head, causing a massive blood spray. Just a drop hits your 
cut knee and enters your bloodstream, and BAM! You're a zombie now.

So yeah. In a zombie apocalypse, NOBODY is likely to survive. Some are just 
more likely to die than others.

comments.text:
+Jared Bruce
Ignoring the "global warming" rhetoric, which I can't determine being 
between genuine paranoia or unoriginal trolling, fungus do mutate. I'm not 
sure if you don't understand the definition of mutation and only attribute 
it to things like being able to control metal, shoot beams out of your 
eyes, and such, but a mutation is any permanent change in an organism's 
DNA. This is how evolution works. No matter if you believe we evolved from 
single-celled organisms unquantifiable time periods ago, God created the 
universe in 7 days, or any other theory of the origin of life, it is 
undeniable that evolution through mutation occurs in all living organisms 
(and btw, last time i checked Fungi was one of the 6 kingdoms of life 
alongside animals, protizoa, chromista, bacteria, and plants (which are not 
the same thing as fungi). An example is 2 parent deer with light brown fur 
give birth to 3 fawns. Of these 3, 2 fawns have the same color fur as the 
parents, but 1, who we shall name Greg (Why, cause it's a cool name). The 
gene for fur color in Greg mutated, and any of Greg's offspring will have 
that gene passed down to them, but that's only if Greg survives. If say 
Greg's color was a darker brown than the parents and they live in a heavily 
wooded forest, Greg would blend into woods better, and be less likely to 
attract the attention of predators than the rest of his family and 
therefore have a better chance at survival. The opposite is also true 
though, say Greg came out much lighter brown or even white. Due to Greg's 
not so subtle color difference from the rest of the environment, he is 
unlikely to survive and therefore the gene doesn't get passed down. But 
just like the how mutation can be unpredictable, so can mother nature. What 
if, after Greg is born with much lighter colored fur than his parent's, an 
ice age hits (Ridiculous yes, but not impossible. It's not like deer can 
monitor world weather patterns and plan accordingly). Assuming Greg, his 
family, their food source, and the predators are able to survive the new 
climate, then Grags new lighter color will give him a better chance at 
surviving than the rest of his darker family. He will survive, reproduce 
and pass on his light color fur gene, giving his offspring better chances 
at surviving and breeding and passing it on again. The same can happen with 
cordyceps or any other disease. An offspring with a mutation that allows it 
to infect humans can be born at any time, and if during its lifetime it 
comes in contact with a human, then it begins flourish and pass on that 
gene, eventually changing the disease all together.
comments.author: Daniel

comments.text:
Internal fungal infections are commonplace in humans.  Cryptococcus 
neoformans (fungal meningitis) for instance is a major cause of death in 
HIV patients and in healthy people it infects the lungs (it cannot get 
purchase in the brain without a weakened immune system).

This is the most common dangerous one, but internal fungal infections are 
fairly commonplace.
comments.author: Jimmy De'Souza

comments.text:
Have you ever heard of random mutations and natural selection? Granted, I'm 
not saying that it is probable that a fungus could mutate to the point that 
it is capable of surviving in surviving in a complex creature such as 
ourselves that also uses metabolic heat regulation, but that's kind of the 
nature of mutation.  Over a really long time scale, such a mutation becomes 
a more likely probability, but is still reliant completely upon chance. 
 And if such a mutation did happen, it would have no competitors since it 
would be the only cordyceps to prey upon endotherms, so it would likely 
spiral out of control.  However, it would also have to simultaneously 
undergo a mutation that involves a more effective response against the 
immune system. Most macrophages wouldn't take too kindly to foreign 
objects.  Such a mutation is possible and even plausible, but not likely.

So you are wrong, it does have a chance of happening, the probability is 
just incredibly low that the two most necessary mutations would appear in 
the wild in tandem.  But if they did, the entire situation is completely 
plausible, since patient 0 would likely be taken to a hospital for seizure 
or rabies-like symptoms, or wouldn't go in and would manage to affect some 
other people.  That's assuming that such a fungus wouldn't target other 
mammals and propagate along them before first making contact with a human, 
causing the new cordyceps to be widespread before we are even affected.
comments.author: TheFreakindon

comments.text:
All you said was very true.

BUT the idea is still plausible. Honestly, with global warming, it is 
increasing the amount of wild animals that are sick because of parasitic 
based disease. Ticks, chiggers, mosquitoes, (those are based in malaria) 
and fleas are thriving in the warming climate. These bugs are great 
carriers for diseases and viruses, and there are plenty of them. Just as an 
example of what the parasites are doing, moose are dying out. They are 
being eaten alive by ticks. (Not saying that there will be zombie moose 
roaming around, though it's interesting and freaky thought.) Global warming 
is also helping diseases and viruses grow and change. Swine-flu and 
Nile-virus for example. Rabies could be next on the evolution list.

Here's another thought about how the infection could spread. Think about 
densely packed cities, India's major cities* for example. Very packed, 
large quantities of animals around. If someone got bit by an animal at 
work, that person could get infected and then attack a crowd that he/she is 
in. A few people get hurt(cuts or scraps) and they don't think much about 
getting sick from the person who attacked them because they're already 
pissed at him/her. Not knowing they got hurt, process repeats. 1 to 5 to 25 
to 125 to 625 to 3,125 to 15,625 etc. (assuming each person attacks 5 
people) It would be underground for a few days, until a very large quantity 
are infected. Then BOOM! The virus is nearly impossible to control because 
100 of thousands have it. (Seems a bit ridiculous to myself... But still 
possible.) This could be similar to the Black Plague. 

* I don't have anything against India, just an example.

Back to the neural functions. 

The human brain doesn't even need to be "possessed" and lose it's control 
and neural function. The realistic zombie apocalypse is just people that 
are overly violent, aggressive, infected, and have dropped down to primal 
animalistic behavior. They are very sick. So sick that they are only doing 
what the brains is telling the body to do and un-able to make choices. The 
person doesn't even need to eat its prey, it only needs to attack to spread 
the disease. I admit, I don't know what exactly the rabies virus does to 
the brain to, I guess, control the animal/person, but if the viruses 
purpose is to spread, it will make itself spread.
comments.author: Jetsun RPM

comments.text:
Again, the idea of an infected human losing control of his neural functions 
and attacking another human is highly unlikely. Not to mention, that it 
would be contained fairly easily if a virus were to spread that way. The 
only thing that comes close to a zombie like virus in nature is rabies. And 
cases of rabies are rare. It is far more probable that a flue like disease 
would decimate our population though.

comments.author: Lámbientan Lámbientan

comments.text:
+Lámbientan Lámbientan

I only wish you peace. I wish to set your heart at ease. Did you watch the 
video?

Perhaps you speak another language. (Although I have read your response in 
English it says "Translate" below your post...)

The following is a transcript of the video... 

"This is the method I use to manage fear. It has helped me in life or death 
situations. I hope it helps you.
It is possible overcome fear when facing real physical danger, and there 
are some very compelling reasons to learn how, but it's not easy. Having 
the right philosophical scaffolding can help, but in the end it will always 
be up to you.

Let's begin with a reality check This planet is, and has always been a 
dangerous place.

The adrenaline you feel when standing on the edge of a cliff, or when you 
realize that you almost just stepped on a poisonous snake, or when you 
finally come to terms with the fact that the government you live under has 
become a militarized police state... that feeling is there for a reason.

Fear is our physical body recoiling at the prospect of annihilation. Fear 
is a biochemical alarm system which helps keep organisms on this planet 
alive by triggering a fight, flight or freeze response. If the attacker can 
be defeated, fight, if you can outrun it run, if you can't beat it or out 
run it freeze and play dead.

This alarm system has persisted in the gene pool and will continue to 
persist because in many life or death situations it is highly effective. 
Fear, however, is a double edged sword.

Panic can send a herd of buffalo stampeding over a cliff, and it can make a 
crowd of humans behave in much the same way. If you need evidence of this, 
just take a cursory glance at the pages of history, or better yet, take a 
closer look at current events.

Fear doesn't make you smarter. In fact studies have shown that terror 
literally shuts down the rational and logical parts of our brains.

Now it's obviously not a good idea to face dangerous situations, or to make 
important decisions with the most useful parts of our brains turned off, 
but consider the implications of having an entire human society operating 
at this level.

Trouble is, the ruling classes have always understood that it is in their 
interest keep the peasants in a perpetual state of fear and insecurity. 
Those who are able to dictate the nightmares of a nation, usually end up 
dictating everything else.

The stakes are higher than our emotional well being.

The ability to control our fear and reduce or eliminate its hold on the 
mind is what allows us to take INTELLIGENT action in the face of danger. 
Having full use of one's brain also helps to distinguish between real and 
imagined threats. This skill is often referred to as courage.

Courage doesn't just happen randomly. A man doesn't just get up one day and 
perform a triple twisting flip off of a cliff out of the blue. Chances are 
his heart was pounding like crazy the first time he stood at the edge of 
the high dive when he was a kid. The primary difference between an expert 
cliff diver, and someone who passes their whole life paralyzed by their 
fear of heights, is that one of them made themselves jump, and kept doing 
so until it became second nature.

You might gather from this example that the way to defeat one's fear is to 
face it. This is true on one level. If you are afraid of snakes, and you 
handle them long enough, the fear will subside. The same principle applies 
to most individual fears. Trouble is, fear is like a multi-headed hydra. 
Cut off one head and another can grow up to take its place. Furthermore, it 
is often not practical or even possible for us to overcome each little 
phobia and worry through direct exposure. For example it would be foolish 
to attempt to confront one's fear of a dangerous disease like Ebola by 
contracting it.

To overcome fear in a long term, sustainable way, you have to go to the 
root.

But what is the root of fear?

The root of all fear, even seemingly petty and insignificant fear is, 
death. Social anxiety for example can be traced to the primal need to be 
well integrated into one's family and tribe. Being rejected by one's peers 
was a death sentence in ancient times, and still is today in some 
societies. This primitive legacy leaves most humans unable to resist the 
forces of social conformity and authority.

Being unconscious of the root, makes the irrational byproducts impossible 
to process.


 
This underlying fear of death is the body of the hydra. Facing it 
effectively is the key to freedom.

We all live under the shadow of annihilation, whether we consciously 
acknowledge it or not. You are going to die. I am going to die. In three 
hundred years every single one of us will be dust. No one leaves this place 
alive, and there is no getting around that reality (though some convince 
themselves otherwise).

Do you find that thought disturbing? Does it fill you with dread and 
despair? Whatever you do don't look away. Hidden within that discomfort is 
the secret of life.

You see death is the ultimate councilor. It is the ultimate point of 
reference.

Will this thing that you are afraid of matter in three hundred years? In 
most cases you'll find that the answer is no.

Regardless of how dire your situation may seem, no matter how serious your 
personal problems may be death will erase them for you someday. Once you 
fully integrate this reality, you'll find that it is a relief. Just a short 
internal glance at one's tombstone can be used to release those surface 
level fears. Take a deep breath, let it go, and do what needs to be done.

We are dust in the wind.

There is absolutely no sense in poisoning the precious little time that we 
have with inner turmoil. You're going to die no matter what, so you might 
as well look your death in the eye and smile like a kid who's been caught 
with their hand in the cookie jar, but eats the cookie anyway.

But what if the answer is yes? What if this issue that's keeping you up at 
night WILL matter in three hundred years? Well, what would you do about it 
if you weren't afraid? What would you do if you knew you only had a year 
left to live? Answer that question and you have found your mission in life. 
You have found something bigger than yourself. Something worth dying for is 
worth living for.

Are you are afraid of walking your path? Then take another look at your 
grave.

Ironically confronting your death can also help you avoid it. Those who 
have accepted the inevitable actually have a tactical advantage over those 
who are terrified of it. Courage is a wild card which can turn the tables 
against impossible odds. (300) A small group of highly motivated, fearless 
individuals can accomplish far more than an army of cowardly and obedient 
sheep.

Remember, we can negotiate the time table to some infinitesimally small 
degree, but no matter what we do our lifespans are short like sparks on 
their one fleeting trajectory of existence.

You want to really live? You want to make that spark count? You want it to 
start a fire before it goes out? Then don't sleepwalk passively towards the 
gallows.

Stand up, look your death in the eye and dance like you're never going to 
dance again, sing like you're never going to sing again, stand up while 
your heart is still beating and hold your child like this moment is all you 
have, because it is."
comments.author: 24kGoldenRocket

comments.text:
+George Linkoln

It is a fact that you will die even if there is NOT a Thermonuclear War. 

Disease, Accidents, or Systemic Organ Failure from Old Age are far more 
likely to end your life.

Like it, or not, you are, someday, going to die. It is unavoidable.

It has been said that today is the first day of the rest of your life. That 
is not true on the day that you die.

When you come to grips with that fact and are able to laugh at it in the 
face of it then you will realize an absolute freedom from any fears that 
you have.

So why don't you concentrate on living with what time that you have been 
gifted with, to the fullest, instead of worrying about death, an event 
which you are powerless to prevent?

comments.text:
All nuclear reactors have safety mechanisms that will automatically shut 
down if certain parameters are met.  The Fukushima reactor leak , Three 
Mile Island, and Chernobyl were specific events with abnormal circumstances 
that defeated (at that time) those safety features.  Events like these are 
then taken and studied to figure out what can be done to prevent something 
like this from happening again.  The studies are then tested and new safety 
mechanisms are installed in current/future reactors.  It's not as simple as 
"fuck, that thing is still running and will meltdown."  It's more like 
"ISIS attacked that plant among the chaos of this infection, studied the 
tech manual, defeated the safety mechanism, and is sabotaging the plant to 
cause a meltdown.

A key point in this video that was missed out is that Cordyceps fungus has 
taken over animals much bigger than ants. Arachnids have been recorded with 
it and even mammals like horses and dogs have had it, meaning we could well 
be on our way to it happening, whether it's in 1 year or 100. Fungus' grow 
much more rapidly than many people think, and have the power to evolve and 
adapt to larger mammals. If an outbreak within humans did occur, it 
wouldn't be like The Last Of Us, where everything goes to hell and half the 
world dies, but places without satisfactory medical care could be wiped 
out. I guess time will tell us whether or not this will happen.
comments.author: PhanIs OnFire

comments.text:
A targeted genetic mutation of any disease would be devastating but it 
doesn't mean we'd see an impact anywhere near the level we see in Last of 
Us. Sure bacteria and viruses cause a great deal of physiological 
suffering, but to put on the same level as a mind controlling bug, not even 
close man. In terms of cognition viruses and bacteria don't cause you to 
negate self preservation and non have altered the person entirely, they 
alter mood yes but the cordyceps in the game turn humans into raving 
monsters. Its easy to engineer bacteria and viruses, but fungi? Its like 
any other animal it would take years and years of successfully breeding in 
order to reach a level that scientists desire. And even then, its gonna be 
awfully difficult to get a cordycep to pass the blood brain barrier and 
produce the same effects present in the game. I highly doubt its plausible 
for the same reasons we haven't seen a zombie virus yet.
comments.author: lancasterjr

comments.text: what if a group of fucked up scents did evolve this disease ????
comments.author: houssem nabouli

comments.text:
+lancasterjr Actually, bacterias and viruses can have a pretty significant 
impact on how humans function. A common urinary tract infection will 
commonly cause significant cognitive impairment and changes in mood. These 
bacteria create changes in the biochemical environment within the body, 
which in turn affects the way the body (and eventually the mind) function. 

While standard evolution wouldn't produce this effect from cordyceps very 
quickly, a targeted genetic mutation, such as a weaponization potential 
of cordyceps could very easily change these fungi to produce similar 
effects in humans as they do in their regular prey.
comments.author: Jacob Watkins

comments.text:
+Benjamin Persson None of those things "take over humans". We suffer from 
the symptoms those organisms cause, yes, but we have never had a bacteria 
or virus virulent and complex enough to control a human. Plus, you are 
ignoring what he said about evolution, there is no need for this fungi to 
"jump" species it propagates fine within the ecosystems it exists within 
now. On top of that, the chances of it causing the symptoms in the actual 
game are next to impossible. The reason those organisms adapt are because 
they undergo evolutionary pressure from humans and begin to evolve. 
Bacteria are so numerous that once they begin to develop immunities, those 
bacteria that reproduced are selected for almost immediately. This simply 
wouldn't happen with a fungus.
comments.author: lancasterjr

captions.text:
Hey Vsauce, I'm Jake and in the incredible
game The Last of Us 60% of the global population,

4.25 billion people, more than the entirety
of Asia, have suddenly ceased to exist or

are just no longer people. And scenarios like
this are nothing new, there have been hundreds

and hundreds of movies and videogames that
cover similar events, but could a pandemic

like what is depicted in The Last of Us...actually
happen?

You only have to go back 95 years to 1918,
at the end of World War 1, to witness one

of the most deadly and disastrous pandemics
in human history: The Spanish Flu.

This variety of avian influenza killed an
estimated 50 to 100 million people, more than

3 times the amount who died in the actual
war, and with a worldwide population at the

time of 1.85 billion, it wiped out 3-5% of
the entire planet; and that was only in one
year.

But the flu is a virus that actually exists,
and in the work of fiction The Last of Us

we are dealing with an organism, a fungus...that
also...actually exists.

Cordyceps are fungal parasites that infect
and take over insects. The most well known

being ophiocordyceps unilateralis that infects
ants, turning them into zombies. A spore from

the fungus enters the ant's body, taking over
its brain and controlling its movements. Not

too long after, the ant finds a perfect spot
to die, the fruiting body of the fungus grows

out of the ant's head, and a slew of spores
are released onto the unsuspecting ant population.

It has been known to decimate entire colonies,
but luckily it only infects insects, and it's

not like diseases can move from one species
to another...well....

An estimated 60% of all modern diseases came
from animals, specifically ones that we live

in close contact with or have domesticated.
From cattle grew measles, tuberculosis and

smallpox. From pigs and birds we have the
flu. From chimpanzees we have AIDS. All of

these started out as infections that couldn't
be spread to humans, but after years and years

of these microbes being around us, they adapted
to our biology.

But we don't live in direct contact with ants,
and most people don't eat ants, so that's

good...but other animals do, and then other
animals eat those animals, and at some point
on this parasitic food chain lie humans. Considering how diseases mutated and progressed from domesticated

animals to us, it isn't too far fetched to
think that a fungal infection like this, whose

only purpose is to survive long enough to
spread, could adapt and evolve to lay claim
to the top of that food chain.

A great example of a microbe's ingenuity is
in Jared Diamond's amazing book 'Guns, Germs

and Steel'. Jared talks about the bacterial
disease typhus and how it was transmitted

to people by going from rat fleas to rats
to humans. But after a while, typhus figured

out a much easier way to infect us: by cutting
out the unnecessary carriers and going directly
from human body lice to humans.

If a fungal parasite like the Cordycep could
infect humans like it does in The Last of

Us, how long would it take? One of the biggest
differences between the Spanish Flu in 1918

and a modern day pandemic is how connected
we are. What would have taken two weeks to

go from New York to Germany by boat, can be
done in 8hrs on a plane. Using the Global
Epidemic and Mobility software and some parameters we know from the game, we can create a model

and simulate what the transmission and spread
would look like.

In about 60 days, the fungal parasite would
have infected the majority of the planet.

And you know things are bad when not even
Madagascar is safe.

But that isn't to say that the governments
of the world don't have plans in place. Most

governments - and the United States in particular
- have strategies for biological threats,

counterterrorism, and the one that applies
to this situation most, The National Strategy

for Pandemic Influenza. In it their high estimate
for fatality domestically is 2 million, or

less than 1% the population of the US. This
incredibly detailed 233 page document really

drives home one main point, and that is "sustain
infrastructure and mitigate impact to the
economy and the functioning of society".

A virus or disease or parasite doesn't affect
power lines, cars, the internet...it affects

the people who make those things work. When
60% of the entire population, over 4 billion

people, just stop being - when the doctors,
the teachers, the mechanics, the mail men

vanish, and what we know as society crumbles...all
that's left is...the last of us.
And as always, thanks for watching.

title: Could We Be The Last of Us?
